body_html:
Regarding error 2: indices = np.arrange(len(x_train)) appears to be a typo, but in the current version of imdb.py this has been fixed (on Aug 1).

I cannot reproduce the library problem.

Importing directly from tensorflow.python is definitely not a good idea. Here's a workaround (though this style of import should really work). I have tested this on 1.8, so it's not a new thing:

>>> import tensorflow as tf
>>> imdb = tf.keras.datasets.imdb
>>> imdb
<module 'tensorflow.tools.api.generator.api.keras.datasets.imdb' from '/Users/wicke/Library/Python/2.7/lib/python/site-packages/tensorflow/tools/api/generator/api/keras/datasets/imdb/__init__.pyc'>
>>> dir(imdb)
['__builtins__', '__doc__', '__file__', '__name__', '__package__', '__path__', 'get_word_index', 'load_data']
>>>

I cannot reproduce the library problem.
Importing directly from tensorflow.python is definitely not a good idea. Here's a workaround (though this style of import should really work). I have tested this on 1.8, so it's not a new thing:

>>> imdb = tf.keras.datasets.imdb

<module 'tensorflow.tools.api.generator.api.keras.datasets.imdb' from '/Users/wicke/Library/Python/2.7/lib/python/site-packages/tensorflow/tools/api/generator/api/keras/datasets/imdb/__init__.pyc'>

body:
Regarding error 2: `indices = np.arrange(len(x_train))` appears to be a typo, but in the current version of imdb.py this has been fixed (on Aug 1).

I cannot reproduce the library problem. 

Importing directly from tensorflow.python is definitely not a good idea. Here's a workaround (though this style of import should really work). I have tested this on 1.8, so it's not a new thing:

```python
>>> import tensorflow as tf
>>> imdb = tf.keras.datasets.imdb
>>> imdb
<module 'tensorflow.tools.api.generator.api.keras.datasets.imdb' from '/Users/wicke/Library/Python/2.7/lib/python/site-packages/tensorflow/tools/api/generator/api/keras/datasets/imdb/__init__.pyc'>
>>> dir(imdb)
['__builtins__', '__doc__', '__file__', '__name__', '__package__', '__path__', 'get_word_index', 'load_data']
>>> 
```
